docs.lead_paragraph: Eighteen years ago, I worked as a researcher on a psychiatric ward. One of the central diagnostic indices used to determine the severity of patients' illnesses was to assess their ''insight.'' Did they understand how and the degree to which they were not well? They usually did not. But over the course of their treatment, the cure was frequently more painful than the affliction, never more so than when patients first became aware of their past behavior, their dementia-fueled outbursts against loved ones, staff and themselves. They now found themselves stranded in a no-man's land between delusion and clarity -- often sad, occasionally humorous. One psychiatrist picked up the phone one day to a panicked, unidentified voice warning of an impending attack at a certain foreign embassy. ''Why call me?'' asked the doctor. ''Why not tell the embassy?''

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00; Incompetence Is Bliss

docs.abstract: David Rakoff article on study that found few of subjects tested on skill levels in number of areas had any idea how incompetent they were; notes study found those who scored lowest on objective tests scored highest in own self-evaluation, while high-scoring subjects underestimated their skills and how well they compared with others; holds self-deception is necessary, despite its limitations; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW YORK City obstetrician lost his license last week for carving his initials into the belly of a patient after he delivered her first child. The incident and the actions taken afterward have raised ethical questions about the responsibilities of American hospitals and legal ones about when doctors should face criminal prosecution, and not just malpractice suits.
docs.abstract: Handling of incident in which obstetrician, Dr Allan Zarkin, cut his initials into patient's belly after delivering baby raises ethical questions about responsibilities of hospitals and legal ones about when doctors should face criminal prosecution; Beth Israel Medical Center forced Zarkin to resign, but did not call police; most medical injury cases have gone to court as civil malpractice suits rather than criminal or intentionally wrongful injury cases; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Britain Intensifies Effort To Get I.R.A. to Disarm Britain moved to suspend the power-sharing government in Northern Ireland by next week, but said it would work to get paramilitary forces to begin disarming before using that authority. A1 Rightists in Austria Coalition Austria's president announced that he would swear in a new government today that includes the anti-immigrant Freedom Party of Jorg Haider, after a day of hesitation that was marked by objections to two Freedom Party members as proposed cabinet ministers. docs.lead_paragraph: The State Department of Health fined Beth Israel Medical Center $14,000 yesterday and ordered it to improve its oversight of doctors after an inquiry into a hospital obstetrician who carved his initials into a patient's belly. The seven citations issued against Beth Israel, each carrying the maximum fine of $2,000, are one of the harshest rebukes against a New York hospital in recent years.

headline.main: Health Officials Fine Hospital Where Doctor Carved Patient

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying they feared dietary supplements' unknown effects on fetuses, two leading experts in birth defects asked the Food and Drug Administration today to revoke a new rule that allows supplement manufacturers to market products for morning sickness and leg swelling in pregnancy. The rule, to take effect on Monday, permits the makers to sell herbal products and other supplements for those pregnancy-related conditions without subjecting them to the safety and effectiveness testing that is required of prescription drugs.

headline.main: F.D.A. Draws Fire for a Rule on Supplements and Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Two leading experts in birth defects, saying that they fear dietary supplements' unknown effects on fetuses, ask FDA to revoke new rule that allows manufacturers to market products for morning sickness and leg swelling in pregnancy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth Israel Medical Center resigned from his post yesterday amid inquiries involving a doctor who was suspended in September for carving his initials into a patient's belly, the hospital said. Hospital officials did not give a reason for the resignation. But the move came after reports that the chairman, Dr. Daniel Saltzman, met in November with Dr. Allan Zarkin, the obstetrician involved in the carving incident. Dr. Zarkin had become medical director of a Queens women's clinic, and the two men met to discuss setting up a nurse-midwives program to give prenatal care to clinic patients.

headline.main: As Inquiry Into Carving by Doctor Goes On, Hospital Official Quits

docs.abstract: Dr Daniel Saltzman, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth Israel Medical Center, resigns from his post amid inquiries involving Dr Allan Zarkin, who was suspended in September for carving his initials into patient's belly (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than a week after a 31-year-old woman joyously announced to the world that she was pregnant with septuplets, all seven fetuses died on Monday because of an infection in her uterus, her doctors said today. The woman, Ivette Zapata-Smalls of Lakewood, N.J., was in stable condition tonight after miscarrying the fetuses, which at 19 1/2 weeks were three weeks short of being viable outside the womb. Citing strong religious beliefs against abortion, Mrs. Zapata-Smalls and her husband, Frederick Smalls, had rejected their obstetrician's advice to abort four or five of the embryos, which would have enhanced the survival rate for the remaining fetuses.

headline.main: An Infection Kills a New Jersey Woman's Unborn Septuplets

docs.lead_paragraph: Two months after an obstetrician was suspended from Beth Israel Medical Center for carving his initials into a patient's belly, hospital officials met with him to discuss sending nurse midwives to work at a Queens clinic where the doctor had a new job, the hospital acknowledged yesterday. The obstetrician, Dr. Allan Zarkin, met with Dr. Daniel Saltzman, chief of obstetrics at Beth Israel, and other hospital personnel in mid-November to talk about setting up a midwives program with Choices Women's Medical Center, which offers abortions and gives prenatal care.

headline.main: Hospital That Suspended Doctor Met Him Later About Joint Project

docs.lead_paragraph: Asthma and infections like pneumonia and bronchitis accounted for more than half the hospitalizations of children from 1 to 4 years old in a major study of children's health in the United States. The research, the most comprehensive in a decade, also found that the conditions were responsible for nearly a third of hospital stays for 5- to 9-year-olds. Among 15- to 17-year-olds, 3 out of 10 hospitalizations were for pregnancy or childbirth. And for younger adolescents, depression and other mental disorders were the main diagnoses, accounting for more than 9 percent of hospital stays for 10- to 14-year-olds, compared with less than 2 percent for adults.

headline.main: Why Children End Up in the Hospital
